float computeDistance ( MiddleEarth &  me,
string  start,
vector< string >  dests 
)

Computes the full distance of the cycle.

Parameters:
me The instance of the MiddleEarth that contains all of the location data
start The starting and ending location of the cycle
dests The list of locations
Returns:
A float representing the total distance traveled in the cycle
Note:
dests does not contain start

This method will compute the full distance of the cycle that starts at the 'start' parmater,
goes to each of the cities in the dests vector IN ORDER, and ends back at the 'start' parameter.

int main ( int  argc,
char **  argv 
)

The main of the program.

Parameters:
argc The number of supplied command line arguments
argv A double pointer to a character containing the arguments
Note:
The user ends to supply no more and no less than 5 additional arguments for the program (The first is the executable).

Assumes the parameters are well-formed after checking the number of parameters.
Then, constructs the world of MiddleEarth from parameters.
Afterwards, constructs the iterinerary and removes the starting destination from the list
Finally, generates all permutations of the paths and keeps smallest one, which is printed to the console.

string printRoute ( string  start,
vector< string >  dests 
)

Records the entire route travelled.

Parameters:
start The starting/ending location in MiddleEarth
dests A vector containing the locations that will be travelled through
Returns:
A string representing the route.
This method will print the entire route, starting and ending at the 'start' parameter.
Note:
The output should be of the form:
Erebor -> Khazad-dum -> Michel Delving -> Bree -> Cirith Ungol -> Erebor
